poem:
Title: "The Great Divide"

Shattered pillars of democracy teeter,
From Berlin's breath to Israel's weather,
Election's echo, justice's meter,
In tangled dance, struggle together.

A people's whisper, law's firm hand,
In a world's stage too grand to span.
The discord rings in every land,
From Washington's heart to the Thames' strand.

In this, our human law-stitched quilt,
Shall justice or majority tilt?
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "From Germany to Israel, it’s ‘the will of the people’ v the rule of law. Which will win? | Paul Taylor The will of the people expressed in free elections and the rule of law upheld by independent courts are two of the pillars of a liberal democracy, or so we were taught at school. Yet these two core principles keep colliding in increasingly polarised societies from Washington to London, Paris to Berlin and Warsaw". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
